com.martinandersson.javaee.utils

Class HttpRequests

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.martinandersson.javaee.utils.HttpRequests

  • public final class HttpRequests
extends Object
    Procedures for making HTTP/1.1 request to the test server.

    All requests made with this class are non-persistent, meaning that the header Connection: close is included in the request sent to the server. After receiving this header, HTTP compliant web servers must close the connection after the response.

    Note that the underlying Java entity used to make HTTP requests by this class is HttpURLConnection which most likely uses pooled connections. Therefore, invoking these methods in a concurrent test has limited effects. Consider using a Socket instead (which we will add in this class in the future, or change the implementation of this method).

    Author:
    Martin Andersson (webmaster at martinandersson.com)

    • Method Detail

      • keepSessionAlive

        public static boolean keepSessionAlive()
        Make all URL connections keep the server side session alive, on a best effort.

        The client will use a cookie handler that keep all cookies. This method will not reinstall an already installed cookie handler. If this method does not make an attempt to install the keep-all cookie handler, then false is returned.

        Client code is advised to wrap this call like so: 

         @BeforeClass
 public static void keepSessionAlive() {
     assertTrue(HttpRequests.keepSessionAlive());
 }
        Even if this method return true, then that is no guarantee the session will be kept alive. Test code that depend on the session object and which fail should examine whether or not the session stays the same over many requests. For example, by using HttpSession.getId().
        Returns:
        true if a new cookie handler was installed, otherwise false

      • getBytes

        public static byte[] getBytes(URL contextRoot,
                              String path,
                              HttpRequests.RequestParameter... parameters)
        Will make a GET-request to the provided Servlet test driver and return the raw response body as a byte[].

        Servlets that do not respond with anything will make the client see a a byte array of zero length.

        A specified path is optional and may be null or the empty String. In this case, the deployed test servlet is mapped to be listening on the application context root 1 or mapped to be the default servlet of the application 2. In both cases, it doesn't matter which path is added to the application context root as the target Servlet will become the target of the request.

        1 url pattern = ""
        2 url pattern = "/"

        Parameters:
        contextRoot - deployed application URL ("application context root"), provided by Arquillian
        path - path to servlet (may be null or empty)
        parameters - each parameter will be added to the GET-request
        Returns:
        object returned by the test driver

      • getObject

        Returns:

      • getObject

        public static <T> T getObject(URL contextRoot,
                              String path,
                              HttpRequests.RequestParameter... parameters)
        Will make a GET-request to the provided Servlet test driver and return an expected Java object as response.

        If Servlet return nothing, null is returned.

        A specified path is optional and may be null or the empty String. In this case, the deployed test servlet is mapped to be listening on the application context root 1 or mapped to be the default servlet of the application 2. In both cases, it doesn't matter which path is added to the application context root as the target Servlet will become the target of the request.

        1 url pattern = ""
        2 url pattern = "/"

        Type Parameters:
        T - type of returned object
        Parameters:
        contextRoot - deployed application URL ("application context root"), provided by Arquillian
        path - path to servlet (may be null or empty)
        parameters - each parameter will be added to the GET-request
        Returns:
        object returned by the test driver

      • getText

        public static String getText(URL contextRoot)
        Will make a GET-request to the deployed Servlet test driver and return the response body as a String (lines separated with System.lineSeparator().

        The deployed test servlet is assumed to be listening on the application context root 1 or mapped to be the default Servlet of the application 2.

        1 url pattern = ""
        2 url pattern = "/"

        Parameters:
        contextRoot - deployed application URL ("application context root"), provided by Arquillian
        Returns:
        the response body

      • sendGetObject

        public static <T> T sendGetObject(URL contextRoot,
                                  String path,
                                  Serializable toSend)
        Will make a POST-request to the provided Servlet test driver and return an expected Java object as response.

        The POST body will contained the provided toSend object in its binary form.

        This method is largely equivalent with getObject(URL, String, RequestParameter...).

        Type Parameters:
        T - type of returned object
        Parameters:
        contextRoot - deployed application URL ("application context root"), provided by Arquillian
        path - path to servlet (may be null or empty)
        toSend - serialized and put in body of the POST request
        Returns:
        object returned by the test driver
